To my Lord Treasuror
Belgia: 1591: Ja
n
May it please yo
r
good L. Heare is great expectation of
her
Ma
t
resolution, about
e Companies intended to be drawen
frome hence. The
States
have assembled their chiefest Gouverno
rs
and c
o
maunders in martiall affaires, w
th
whom they purpose to
determin, how their forces this sommer may bee best employed.
They seeme to make acchount that if the English men remaine
they wilbee able for the space of 7 monethes to bring 8000 foote
and toward
2000 horse into
e field. And this they think will
suffice, either wholie to divert the Ennemy from
Fraunce,
or
to endommage him otherwise very mightely at home. As yet
they have not mett to consult of any thing, attending as it
semeth, how her Ma
tie
will proceed. For unles they bee
assisted by the English troupes, as far as I can
ceave, their
meaning is this sommer, but to fortifie their places, and to
assure their owne estate, w
th
out medling any further. In
effect the want of understanding, how her Hig
nes
is affected
for the 20 companies, doth putt us all that are heer in
continuall care. The more a great deale, for that the
Deputies of
S
r
John Norreis
, not knowing of themselves the
condition of this state, and requiring no advise of us that
are heer, take a dangerous cowrse in the execution of
their charge, For w
th
out respect to the fittest opportunities
or other necessarie circumstances, they command the Captaines
by their letters, to discharge the souldiers out of hand,
as they will answeare the contrarie to their uttermost perils.
W
th
all they enjoyne the
Treasurers Deputie
, to surcease the
paiment of their weekly lending
, w
ch
being certified of late
to
e souldiers of
Breda,
they came imediately, and required
the
Gouverno
r
, to graunt them licence to bee gon, or to
give them entertainment. The
Gouverno
r
being charged by
the States, to suffer none to depart, for the avoiding of a
mutinie, or some oth
r
inconvenience, was forced to deliver them
vittailes, from out of
e magasin of
e garrison. Complaint
coming hether against this disorder, I writ unto
e Captaines
to beare a better hand among the souldiers, and to provide
for the indempnitie of
e publick magazin. What hath ensewed
upon it, I do not yet understand: nor I am not certain,
whether the Captaines either thear, or els wheare, have
actuallie proceeded to
e cassing of their Companies. But for
mine owne part, for asmuch as her Ma
ty
hath vouchsafed bothe

n
in that Commission w
ch
S
r
John Norreis receaved, and in
her letters to
e Councell of State, as likewise to my self,
to specifie precisely, that in the conduct of this action my
advise should be used, and because I have considered as
carefully of it as is possible for mee, and do finde it
every mans opinion, for the reasons I alleaged in my former
letters to yo
r
L. that this course of cassing is full of
inconvenience, I have counsailed all
e Captaines and Officers
of
e foresaid bandes, to innovate nothing in their garrisons
till her Ma
t
pleasure shalbee notified further. For
this will follow of necessitie, that after they are cassed;
bicause the States have
vided, that they shall not bee
transported, w
th
any shipping of these countrys, they must
bee forced to attend for meanes out of
England.
And in
that case
Berghen
being but half a daies Journey from
Flushing,
Breda but one daie, and
Duisbourgh
but 4
or 5 at
e most, to dissolve
e Companies so long befor
would serve to litell purpose, for their speedie transportation.
Moreover, consydering how the winde hath stoode for this
fortnighte, and c
o
tinueth at this p
nt
, it was much to bee
feared,
that
when the troupes had bin disharged, so many men
for so long a time, and all at liberty, would never keep together
w
th
out some notable diminution of their nombers, and great
confusion and disorder otherwise: especially when the people
of
e Countrey shall both refuse to admit them to their towne
and minister no assistance for their vittailes and passage,
And though it may bee presumed, that to bee ridd of such
guest
, the countrey will ordaine, that they should have
meanes to depart, yet undoubtedly they are so bent, that
there is nothing to bee gotten at their handes but by violence
and untell they see by a second charge, that her Hig
nes
[.]
determin to overrule them heerin, they will cutt of
[.]
possibility for the souldiers to be shipped.
The consyderation heerof, and of divers oth
r
point
[that I]
have written of before doth move mee to endev
[or]
mine owne parte, and to advise the Captaines in li
[ke .]
to proceed as orderly and quickly, as convenient
[ly]
w
th
out either troubling the state, or pre
[judicing]

nes

to yo
r
